choices.text: Sputum production more than 100ml/day is bronchorrhea
Significant expectoration involves mucopurulent sputum production
Significant expectoration is common in Interstitial lung disease
Non-significant expectoration is common in cases of Upper respiratory tract infection

questions.text: Respiratory system disorders commonly present with cough. Following statements are true regarding the symptom EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Significant expectoration is common in Interstitial lung disease

Cough is a common symptom of respiratory system disorders. Based on the sputum production, the cases can be classified into “Significant” and “non-significant” expectoration. Normal sputum production is 60-100ml/day. Quantity more than 100ml/day is bronchorrhea. The presence of bronchorrhea, mucopurulent sputum with hemoptysis is significant expectoration. It is common in Airway/parenchymal disorders.

Non-significant expectoration is common feature in Upper respiratory tract infection. It is also seen in Interstitial and Pleural disorders

questions.text: A 70 years old obese gentleman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of breathlessness. He is a known case of type 2 DM for 10-12 years with poor compliance for antidiabetic drugs. He smokes 20 cigarettes/day for the past 40 years. He was diagnosed as COLD and started on bronchodilator inhalation 10 years back, but he has no further follow-up. He gives history of progressive worsening of breathlessness which is associated with exertion for past 6 months. What is best test in the emergency room to diagnose heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pro-BNP assay

The patient with acute onset breathlessness has risk factor for COLD (Chronic smoker) as well as Ischemic heart disease (Male gender, age, Obesity, uncontrolled DM). Hence it is important to first differentiate between Cardiac and respiratory causes of the symptom.

Breathlessness related to exertion is characteristic of Cardiac cause. In the given case, considering a decade of COLD, progression to Cor pulmonale is suggested once the symptoms correlate with exertion. Cor pulmonale is Right ventricular strain due to severe underlying lung disease. 

In emergency room, Pro-BNP assay results are available in 7 minutes and is an approved biomarker for Heart failure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with two months of unintentional 6kg weight loss, night sweats, and fevers. He was recently diagnosed as Pulmonary Tuberculosis. At presentation his vital signs were as follows: temperature 38.2°C, heart rate 131bpm, blood pressure 92/48 mmHg, respiratory rate 16bpm, and SpO2 97% in room air with massive recurrent hemoptysis. For angiographic treatment which vascular structure should be evaluated first
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bronchial artery 

MC source of hemoptysis is bronchial artery so for angiographic treatment it should be evaluated first. Rasmussens aneurysm which is rare is involvement of pulmonary artery adjacent to a TB cavity. Though rare, it can be a cause of life-threatening massive hemoptysis.

questions.text: Tiffeneau-Pinelli Index < 0.70 is diagnostic of which lung disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Obstructive lung disease

Tiffeneau-Pinelli index is the ratio of FEV1/FVC on Spirometry.

In Obstructive lung disease, the expiratory volume (FEV1) is predominantly affected leading to lowering of the ratio. Normal value of the ratio is 0.75. Value lower than 0.70 is specific for Obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: FEV1 / FVC is reduced in all of the following conditions EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

FEV1/FVC also called as the Tiffaneau’s Index is the most accurate parameter of the Spirometry. The index is reduced in Obstructive lung disease which includes Asthma, Chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
In Restrictive lung diseases, it is normal or high.

questions.text: In the following Spirometry Flow Volume loops, Figure (a) represents a normal curve. What does curve (b) best represent :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Restrictive pattern. (Various patterns illustrated)

questions.text: DLCO is decreased in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DLCO: (Diffusion capacity of Lung to Carbon mono-oxide)

questions.text: Most common mechanism in Hypoxemia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

V: Q mismatch

Ventilation perfusion mismatch is most common

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of definition of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ARDS is the most severe form of lung injury presenting as Type 1 Respiratory failure due to alveolar atelectasis presenting as bilateral, perihilar pulmonary infiltrates on Radiology.

Type 1 RF has hypoxemia leading to compensatory hyperventilation (Hypocapnea).

choices.text: Ventilation at tidal volumes of 6ml per kg.

questions.text: The following have been shown to improve mortality in ARDS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Low TV ventilation (6ml/kg) is the main recommendation for mechanical ventilation in ARDS. Since >70% of alveoli are collapsed, giving full TV will lead to overdistension and rupture of the normal remaining alveoli.
Steroids have no effective  role.

questions.text: Alveolar arterial O2 gradient is increased in all EXCEPT.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypoventilation can be associated with normal A-a gradient is normal.

questions.text: If a Valid ABG shows presence of Hypoxemia with a Normal Alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient and Respiratory alkalosis, the probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High altitude

Approach to Hypoxemia : Calculate Alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a).

If A-a gradient is normal:      a. Low CO2 – Low FiO2 defect (High Altitude)
(Extra-pulmonary disease)     b. High CO2 – Hypoventilation syndromes


If A-a gradient is high:	Assess response of the A-a to oxygen therapy.	
(Pulmonary disease)

a. If responsive to oxygen  : COPD, ILD, PTE (Disorder of V:Q mismatch) : MC in practise
b. If unresponsive to O2     : Pulmonary edema, Pneumonia, ARDS (Alveolar defect)

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with features of acute pancreatitis. Few days later he developed dyspnoea. His ABG reveals Ph : 7.46 PaCO2 : 25 HCO3 – 22 PaO2 : 55 mm Hg His chest X ray is shown below. What is the type of respiratory failure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type 1 

H/o pancreatitis + acute SOB + hypoxemia on ABG + B/L diffuse pulmonary infiltrates is suggestive of ARDS. In ARDS common is Type 1 respiratory failure

questions.text: Atypical pneumonia can be caused by all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Staph and Streptococci are included under organisms causing classical pneumonia.

choices.text: OP treatment with Clarithromycin 500mg BID for one week
Admit in ward and give Levofloxacin orally 750mg OD + Inj. Ceftriaxone 1G IV BID
Admit in ICCU and give Inj. Ceftriaxone 2G IV OD + IV levofloxacin 750mg OD
Admit in wards and give Piperacillin + tazobactam 4.5 G qid

questions.text: A 30 year previously healthy male came with 2 days fever and cough with purulent sputum. Examination reveals an impaired note with bronchial breathing and crackles and increased vocal resonance. He is alert. Pulse-106/min, BP=100/70. Respiratory rate =24/min. Blood urea=6 mmol/L. Which of the following is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Using CURB65 score to grade the severity of Pneumonia, the above patient can be classified as Mild pneumonia which can be treated on OPD basis with monotherapy using Azithro/Clarithromycin.

questions.text: Pneumatoceles in chest x-ray are characteristically seen in pneumonia due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

All organisms causing necrotizing pneumonia (Staph, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas) can have Pneumatoceles on chest x-ray.

choices.text: Met acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Met alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis

questions.text: Patient with salicyclic acid poisoning has following ABG analysis report- pH:7.12 pCO2:18mm hg HCO3: 12 mmol/l. Resulting acid base abnormality can be best labelled as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis. Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 ± 2 that give the value of 24 to 28 mm hg. Here the given PaCO2 is less and given context of salicylate poisoning which can itself cause respiratory alkalosis, better answer will metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A 26/M presented with progressive dyspnoea on exertion for 5 months. He is a stone crusher. He had a long‐standing cough with whitish sputum production, but denied fever, chills, weight loss, night sweats, and other symptoms. The patient undergoes bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. The effuent appears milky. The cytopathology shows amorphous debris with periodic acid-Schif (PAS)–positive macrophages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis

-	Abnormal accumulation of pulmonary surfactant in the alveolar space

-	MC : Primary form : anti‐GM‐CSF antibody production

-	Secondary form : Silicosis, Hematological malignancies

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:

ph – 7.23

PaCO2 – 70 mm

HCO3 – 25 mEq
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute Respiratory Acidosis

The ABG shows Primary Respiratory acidosis. To differentiate we need to look at the relation to change in pH with change in PaCO2 in Acute vs Chronic disease.

In Acute Respiratory acidosis, there is no time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.4 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.

In Chronic Respiratory acidosis, there is time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.1 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2

questions.text: A 35/F with long-standing asthma is evaluated for a 1-month history of nocturnal asthma symptoms at least weekly and the need to use Salbutamol inhaler daily. Her asthma therapy is a Low-dose inhaled corticosteroid. The patient is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, she has wheezing. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Uncontrolled symptoms of Asthma include: >2 attacks/week or >1nocturnal attack/week.

If uncontrolled with ICS, next drug to add is LABA(Salmeterol/Formeterol).

questions.text: In COPD management most important intervention is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Smoking is the most important risk factor. Even before prophylaxis, cessation of smoking is essential.

questions.text: The principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MDCT-PA (Multi-detector CT Pulmonary Angiography) is the principal imaging test for diagnosis of PTE. Only if it is contraindicated (e.g. Pregnancy) – VQ scan can be done instead.

questions.text:
A 26/F is evaluated for a 4-month history of progressive dyspnea, initially on
exertion only but now also at rest. Clinical findings were compatible with pulmonary
hypertension. PFT and V/Q scan were normal. A right-heart catheterization shows a low cardiac index, elevated pulmonary artery pressures, normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and elevated pulmonary vascular resistance. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Patient has Pulmonary hypertension with Breathlessness at rest (NYHA Class 4)
Since it is severe, the treatment is Prostacyclin analogue- IV Epoprostenol

questions.text: Farmer’s Lung is caused due to exposure to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thermophilic actinomyces

questions.text: A patient presents with following parameters: ph 7.5, pco2 30 mm hg, PaO2 102mmhg and hco3 20 meq/1. Which of following correctly describes the abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diarrhea, Pancreatic fistula and Renal tubular acidosis are causes of Normal Anion gap acidosis.

questions.text: The most common Bone disease in CKI
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Osteitis cystica fibrosa is most common. 

Renal Osteodystrophy in CKI consists of following with corresponding mechanism involved:

1. Osteomalacia                  : Active Vitamin D deficiency

2. Osteitis Cystica Fibrosa : Secondary hyper-parathyroidism

3. Adynamic bone disease : defect in remodelling.

questions.text: The most common form of Anaemia in CKI
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Normochromic

choices.text: Spot urinary Albumin to creatinine ration

questions.text: The most preferred test for detection of Microalbuminuria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Spot urinary ACR

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes with Loin pain. Urine examination shows 120 rbc/hpf. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBC’s in urine. The site of origin is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dysmorphic haematuria is typical of Glomerulonephritis.

When the source of hematuria is the kidney, the RBC pass through the tubule and hence, deformed.

Presence of eumorphic RBC in urine indicates that the source of bleeding is below the renal pelvis.

questions.text: Following parameters indicate “Significant Hematuria” except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

– RBC – 3-100 >/= 3 occasions are needed to qualify as significant hematuria.

choices.text: Muddy Brown cast – Acute Tubular necrosis

questions.text: Which of the following matching is incorrect:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Interstitial Nephritis – Eosinophilia is a specific finding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with bilateral loin pain and frank haematuria. His symptoms started 24hours after developing a sore throat and. His blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg. Urinalysis was positive for blood(4+) and Protein (2+) .Which of the following is expected:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Post-infective GN with a latent period less than 1 week is IgA nephropathy. There is also Frank (Gross haematuria) indicating IgA nephropathy

questions.text: The term end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is considered appropriate when GFR falls to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

5 – 10% of normal

questions.text: Which of these is the most important indication for urgent dialysis in acute renal failure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Indications of Dialysis in AKI:

1. Urea > 100 (Severe azotemia)

2. Refractory Pulmonary oedema

3. Refractory Hyper K+ > 6.5

4. Refractory Metabolic acidosis pH < 7.20

5. Serious Uremic complications

6. Ingestion of Dialysable Toxin (SINGLE MOST IMPORTANT)

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with history of recurrent hematuria during childhood, presents with chronic kidney disease. His maternal uncle died of ESRD 2 years ago. On eye examination, he has an Anterior Lenticonus. The diagnosis IS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Alport’s syndrome – X-linked defect of Type 4 collagen. Manifesting in 2-3rd decade of life with renal failure, Sensori-neural deafness and Anterior Lenticonus /subcapsular cataract.

questions.text: In a patient with early stage of diabetic nephropathy, the most common finding on renal biopsy IS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In DM nephropathy – Biopsy findings:

1. Early stages: Thickening of GBM

2. Late stages:  Nodular Glomerulosclerosis (KW changes)

choices.text: Urine output less than 0.5ml/kg/hr greater than 12 consecutive hours
Urine output less than 0.3ml/kg/hr greater than 12 consecutive hours
Urine output less than 0.5ml/kg/hr greater than 6 consecutive hours
Urine output less than 0.3ml/kg/hr greater than 6 consecutive hours

questions.text: Which one of the following is a Criteria for diagnosis of AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

AKI can be diagnosed using KDIGO guidelines.

1. urine output less than equal to 0.5ml/kg/hr greater than 6 consecutive hours

2. Rise in S.Creatinine greater than 0.3mg/dl from baseline less than 48hours

3. Rise in S.Creatinine greater than 1.5*Baseline less than 7 days

questions.text: The most common extra-renal manifestation in APKD is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic dysfunction due to mechanical compression of IHBR causes cholestatic jaundice.

questions.text: Selective proteinuria is hallmark of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Minimal change disease affects only podocyte function leading to gross albuminuria. Since >99% protein in urine is albumin, it is called selective proteinuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a photosensitive macular rash over the maxilla to a dermatology clinic. She also has pain in the joints for the past 6 months for which she is on NSAIDS. However, there is no deformity. She has no haematuria or dysuria. Urine analysis reveals 3+ proteinuria with granular cast. Which of the following tests are not indicated to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) According to the EULAR update for diagnosis of SLE, the following immunological tests are indicated to confirm diagnosis in a suspected SLE patient. 1. ANA, 2. Anti-sm, 3. Anti-dsDNA, 4. Anti-Phospholipid antibody, 6. Low Serum C3 levels. Direct coomb’s test is neither specific nor sensitive for the diagnosis of SLE and hence has been now approved only for prognosis in confirmed cases of SLE.

questions.text: Anti-centromere antibodies most commonly found with;
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CREST syndrome

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the Rheumatology clinic with 2-month history of stiff joints and wrists. She reports that the pain is especially worse for the first few hours of the morning and is affecting her work as a dentist. On examination, the wrists, MCP and PIP joints are warm and swollen. Squeeze test is positive. Which of the following investigations is most specific for confirming the diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anti-Cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) levels is the most specific antibody for the diagnosis of RA. Serology: Rheumatoid factors (autoantibodies reactive with the Fc portion of IgG): Widely utilized tests mainly detect IgM rheumatoid factors. Sensitive test but non-specific.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female recently diagnosed as a case of rheumatoid arthritis is referred to the rheumatology clinic for ongoing pain in her hands and feet. Which joints are usually spared at the onset of RA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DIP involvement is extremely rare and eve if it occurs, it indicates advanced stage of disease. Early DIP involvement suggests Psoriatic arthropathy or in an elderly suggests OA.

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagia is typically seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Keratoderma Blennorrhagia is typically seen in Reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Feature of axial spondyloarthritis include all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Poor response to NSAIDS

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with Abdominal pain, rashes and palpable purpura with arthritis. Most probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HSP

questions.text: Recurrent bilateral Hypopyon formation associated with oral ulcers is most consistent with which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bechet’s syndrome

questions.text: A 35 years old man presents to you with a 2-month history of pain in his small joints of hands. On examination, nail peeling is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Psoriatic arthritis – Spondyloarthropathy with Skin and Nail changes.

questions.text: Match the organism associated with risk of auto-immune disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1-C, 2-A, 3-E, 4-B
